notes: Das Wort 'Здравей' leitet sich vom bulgarischen Wort 'здрав' (gesund) ab und ist wie ein Wunsch nach Gesundheit.
etymology: From Proto-Slavic 'zdravъ' (healthy) - literally a wish for good health
cultural_note: Standard informal greeting used throughout the day in Bulgaria. More casual than 'Добър ден'
linguistic_note: Stress on first syllable: ЗДРА-вей. Can be shortened to 'Здрасти' in very informal contexts

notes: Formelle Begrüßung, verwendet zwischen 12:00 und 18:00 Uhr
etymology: добър (good) + ден (day) - direct calque from Latin 'bonus dies'
cultural_note: More formal than 'Здравей'. Used in business contexts and with strangers
linguistic_note: Stress pattern: ДО-бър ДЕН. Both words stressed equally

notes: Grundwort für Haus/Zuhause. Unterscheidet sich von 'къща' (physisches Gebäude)
cultural_note: In Bulgarian culture, 'дом' implies emotional connection to home, not just building
linguistic_note: Masculine noun, definite form: 'домът'. Stress on single syllable

notes: Grundlegendes Substantiv für Wasser in allen Kontexten
cultural_note: Bulgarian mineral water culture is significant - 'минерална вода' is preferred
linguistic_note: Feminine noun, definite form: 'водата'. Stress on first syllable: ВО-да

notes: Kann sowohl 'Arbeit' als auch 'Job' bedeuten, je nach Kontext
etymology: From Proto-Slavic 'orbota' - related to 'раб' (slave), but evolved to mean general work
cultural_note: Bulgarian work culture values personal relationships at work more than German efficiency focus
linguistic_note: Feminine noun, definite form: 'работата'. Stress on second syllable: ра-БО-та

notes: Grundwort für Buch. Bulgarisch hat reiche Literaturgeschichte
etymology: From Old Church Slavonic 'кънига', ultimately from Chinese via Turkic languages
cultural_note: Books highly valued in Bulgarian culture - 'Ден на българската просвета' celebrates literacy
linguistic_note: Feminine noun, definite form: 'книгата'. Stress on first syllable: КНИ-га
